docs.title: What is Hawkeye MCP?
docs.text:
Hawkeye MCP Server is a Model Context Protocol server that enables AI assistants like Claude to interact with NeuBird's Hawkeye platform for automated incident investigation and root cause analysis.

With Hawkeye MCP, you can:

  • 🔍 Investigate alerts automatically - AI-powered root cause analysis for your incidents
  • 🔗 Connect multi-cloud environments - AWS, Azure, GCP, Datadog, PagerDuty, and more
  • 🎯 Test instructions safely - Validate and test investigation instructions before deployment
  • 📊 Track performance - Monitor MTTR, time saved, and investigation quality
  • 🤖 Autonomous remediation - Get actionable corrective actions with bash scripts
🚀 Quick Setup

Install via npm and connect to Hawkeye in minutes. Works with Claude Desktop, Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot, and any MCP-compatible client.

🔌 39 Tools

Comprehensive API covering projects, connections, investigations, instructions, and analytics.

📖 Built-in Guidance

Interactive help system with embedded knowledge base. Ask questions and get instant answers.

🧪 Test Before Deploy

Unique instruction testing workflow - validate, apply to session, rerun, and compare results.

docs.title: 🧪 Unique Instruction Testing
docs.text:
Hawkeye MCP is the only incident investigation tool that lets you test instructions before deploying them:

  1. Apply instruction to a single past investigation
  2. Rerun that investigation with the new instruction
  3. Compare the new RCA with the original
  4. Only add to project if it improves results

This prevents bad instructions from affecting all your investigations.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Common questions about Hawkeye MCP Server.

docs.title: What is Hawkeye MCP?
docs.text: Hawkeye MCP Server is a Model Context Protocol server that connects AI assistants (like Claude) to NeuBird's Hawkeye platform for autonomous incident investigation and root cause analysis.

docs.title: What can I do with Hawkeye MCP?
docs.text:
• Investigate alerts automatically with AI-powered RCA
  • Get actionable corrective actions your coding agent can execute
  • Track MTTR and time saved metrics
  • Test investigation instructions before deployment
  • Connect multi-cloud environments (AWS, Azure, GCP)
  • Integrate with monitoring tools (Datadog, PagerDuty, etc.)

docs.title: How much does it cost?
docs.text: Hawkeye MCP Server is free to use. You need a Hawkeye account, which is a commercial product. Contact NeuBird for Hawkeye pricing.

docs.title: Is my data secure?
docs.text: Yes. Hawkeye MCP uses read-only access to your cloud resources and telemetry. All credentials are stored securely by Hawkeye and Neubird is SOC2 certified so you can trust them with security.

docs.title: Which AI clients are supported?
docs.text:
• Claude Desktop - Anthropic's native desktop app
  • Claude Code - Terminal-based AI assistant
  • Cursor - AI-powered code editor
  • GitHub Copilot - VS Code with MCP extension
  • Continue - VS Code extension with MCP support
  • Any MCP-compatible client

See Installation Guide for setup instructions for each client.

docs.title: Do I need Node.js?
docs.text: Yes, Node.js 20 or higher is required.

docs.title: Can I use it without installing globally?
docs.text: Yes, use npx hawkeye-mcp-server to run without installation.

docs.title: Where are credentials stored?
docs.text: In your MCP client configuration file: - Claude Desktop: ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json (macOS) - Claude Code: - ~/.claude.json (user scope - most common) - .mcp.json in project root (project scope - for teams) - Use /mcp command to see which file is being used

docs.title: How many tools are available?
docs.text: 39 tools across 7 categories: - Projects (5) - Connections (10) - Investigations (10) - Instructions (7) - Analytics (4) - Discovery (2) - Help (1)

docs.title: What makes Hawkeye MCP unique?
docs.text: The instruction testing workflow - you can test investigation instructions on past incidents before deploying them, preventing bad instructions from affecting all investigations.

docs.title: How long does an investigation take?
docs.text:
• Typical: 30-90 seconds
  • First investigation: 5-10 minutes (initial connection sync)
  • Complex incidents: Up to 2 minutes

docs.title: Can I investigate past incidents?
docs.text: Yes! Use hawkeye_list_sessions to find past incidents, then hawkeye_continue_investigation to ask follow-up questions.

docs.title: Which cloud providers are supported?
docs.text:
• AWS (CloudWatch, EC2, RDS, Lambda, ECS)
  • Azure (Azure Monitor, VMs, Functions)
  • GCP (Cloud Logging, Monitoring, Compute)

docs.title: Which monitoring tools are supported?
docs.text:
• Datadog
  • PagerDuty
  • New Relic
  • And more...

Ask Claude: "What connection types are available?"

docs.title: Do I need to connect all my cloud providers?
docs.text: No, start with your primary cloud provider and main monitoring tool. Add others as needed.

docs.title: How long does connection sync take?
docs.text:
• First sync: 5-15 minutes depending on resource count
  • Subsequent syncs: Automatic, real-time
  • Large environments: Up to 15 minutes initial sync

docs.title: What permissions do connections need?
docs.text:
• AWS: ReadOnlyAccess IAM policy
  • Azure: Reader role
  • GCP: Viewer role
  • Datadog: Read-only API and app keys

docs.text:

2. Investigate [alert-id or "the first one"]
3. Show me the RCA

docs.title: Can I create investigations without alerts?
docs.text:
Yes! Use manual investigations to analyze issues without existing alerts:

Investigate high latency in payment-service between 2pm-3pm EST on Jan 15.
Users reported checkout taking 30+ seconds.

Use cases: - Proactive analysis before alerts fire - Historical incident research - Testing "what-if" scenarios - Training and documentation

Tip: Be specific! Include service names, timeframes, and symptoms. Vague prompts like "something broke" won't work well.

See Manual Investigations Guide for details.

docs.title: What's the difference between alert_id and session_uuid?
docs.text:
• alert_id: For NEW uninvestigated alerts (use with hawkeye_investigate_alert)
  • session_uuid: For EXISTING investigations (use with hawkeye_continue_investigation)

docs.title: Can I ask follow-up questions?
docs.text: Yes! After getting an RCA, ask: - "Why did this happen?" - "Has this happened before?" - "How can we prevent this?"

docs.title: What if the RCA is wrong?
docs.text:
1. Ask clarifying follow-up questions
  2. Add instructions to guide future investigations
  3. Test instructions on past sessions
  4. Only deploy if RCA improves

docs.title: Can I investigate multiple alerts at once?
docs.text: Yes, in separate Claude conversations. Each conversation can handle one investigation at a time.

docs.title: What are instructions?
docs.text: Instructions guide Hawkeye's investigation behavior: - FILTER: Reduce noise - SYSTEM: Provide context - GROUPING: Group related alerts - RCA: Investigation steps

docs.title: How do I test an instruction?
docs.text:
1. Validate instruction
2. Apply to test session
3. Rerun session
4. Compare new vs old RCA
5. Add to project if improved

docs.title: Can I modify instructions after creating them?
docs.text: You can enable/disable them using hawkeye_update_project_instruction_status. To modify content, delete and recreate.

docs.title: How many instructions should I have?
docs.text:
Start with: - 1-2 SYSTEM instructions (architecture context) - 1 FILTER instruction (priority threshold) - 2-3 RCA instructions (common incident types)

Add more as needed based on incident patterns.

docs.title: What metrics can I track?
docs.text:
• MTTR (Mean Time To Resolution)
  • Time saved vs manual investigation
  • Investigation quality scores
  • Noise reduction from filtering
  • Incident patterns and trends

docs.title: How is "time saved" calculated?
docs.text:
Compares estimated manual investigation time vs actual Hawkeye investigation time.

Example: - Manual estimate: 45 minutes - Hawkeye time: 60 seconds - Time saved: 44 minutes

docs.title: What's a good quality score?
docs.text:
• 85-100: Excellent
  • 70-84: Good
  • <70: Needs improvement (add more instructions)

  3. Add 1-2 connections (primary cloud + monitoring)
  4. Wait for sync
  5. Add basic instructions (SYSTEM + FILTER)
  6. Investigate first alert

  • Monthly: Clean up unused instructions

docs.title: Should I create separate projects for each environment?
docs.text:
Yes, recommended: - Production/Staging/Development projects - Application specific projects - Team specific projects - Alert specific projects

Each can have different connections and instructions. You can use the same connections in multiple projects and by using investigation instructions you can control which alerts gets investigated in each project. This makes it possible to have specialized instructions in separate projects.

docs.title: How do I switch between projects?
docs.text:
Use hawkeye_set_default_project to switch your active project context:

Switch to my Staging project

Or use the project UUID directly:

hawkeye_set_default_project(project_uuid="abc-123...")

Benefits: - No need to specify project_uuid in every command - Quick context switching between environments - Natural language support (use project names) - Default persists for entire MCP session

Example workflow: 

# Set Production as default
Switch to Production project

# All commands now use Production
List my project's connections
Show recent investigations

# Switch to Staging for testing
Switch to Staging project

# Now everything uses Staging
Test the new instruction

The default project is shown with a ⭐ emoji when you list projects.

docs.title: AWS Integration Example
docs.text: Complete guide to integrating Hawkeye with AWS.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Connect Hawkeye to AWS to investigate incidents across: - CloudWatch Logs & Metrics - EC2 Instances - RDS Databases - Lambda Functions - ECS/EKS Services

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• AWS account with admin access (for setup)
  • AWS CLI installed
  • Hawkeye project created

docs.title: Option A: CloudFormation (Recommended)
docs.text:
Create hawkeye-role.yaml:

AWSTemplateFormatVersion: '2010-09-09'
Description: 'Hawkeye ReadOnly IAM Role'

Parameters:
  ExternalId:
    Type: String
    Description: 'External ID for Hawkeye'
    Default: 'hawkeye-external-id-2024'

Resources:
  HawkeyeRole:
    Type: AWS::IAM::Role
    Properties:
      RoleName: HawkeyeReadOnly
      AssumeRolePolicyDocument:
        Version: '2012-10-17'
        Statement:
          - Effect: Allow
            Principal:
              AWS: 'arn:aws:iam::HAWKEYE_ACCOUNT_ID:root'
            Action: 'sts:AssumeRole'
            Condition:
              StringEquals:
                'sts:ExternalId': !Ref ExternalId
      ManagedPolicyArns:
        - 'arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/ReadOnlyAccess'
      Description: 'Read-only access for Hawkeye investigation'

Outputs:
  RoleArn:
    Description: 'Role ARN for Hawkeye'
    Value: !GetAtt HawkeyeRole.Arn
    Export:
      Name: HawkeyeRoleArn

Deploy:

aws cloudformation create-stack \
  --stack-name hawkeye-readonly-role \
  --template-body file://hawkeye-role.yaml \
  --capabilities CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM \
  --parameters ParameterKey=ExternalId,ParameterValue=your-external-id

# Wait for completion
aws cloudformation wait stack-create-complete \
  --stack-name hawkeye-readonly-role

# Get Role ARN
aws cloudformation describe-stacks \
  --stack-name hawkeye-readonly-role \
  --query 'Stacks[0].Outputs[0].OutputValue' \
  --output text

docs.title: Option B: Manual Creation
docs.text:
1. Create Role: 

    aws iam create-role \
  --role-name HawkeyeReadOnly \
  --assume-role-policy-document file://trust-policy.json

  2. Trust Policy (trust-policy.json): 

    {
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Principal": {
        "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::HAWKEYE_ACCOUNT_ID:root"
      },
      "Action": "sts:AssumeRole",
      "Condition": {
        "StringEquals": {
          "sts:ExternalId": "your-external-id-here"
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}

  3. Attach ReadOnly Policy: 

    aws iam attach-role-policy \
  --role-name HawkeyeReadOnly \
  --policy-arn arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/ReadOnlyAccess

14:42 - Database CPU distributed, dropped to 60%

     ON payments(merchant_id);

docs.title: Configuration Scopes
docs.text:
Scope Location Use Case User ~/.claude.json Available in all your projects (most common) Project .mcp.json in project root Shared with team via version control Local ~/.claude.json with project context Private to you in specific project

Which scope should I use?

  • User scope (~/.claude.json) - Best for personal MCP servers you want everywhere
  • Project scope (.mcp.json) - Best for team-shared configurations
  • Local scope - Best for project-specific overrides

docs.title: Method 1: User Configuration (Recommended)
docs.text: This is the most common approach - configure Hawkeye MCP once and use it across all your projects.

docs.title: 1. Locate User Configuration File
docs.text:
The user config file is located at:

~/.claude.json

Open or create the file:

# Open in default text editor
nano ~/.claude.json

# Or use VS Code
code ~/.claude.json

File doesn't exist?

If the file doesn't exist, create it with an empty JSON object: {}

docs.title: 2. Add Hawkeye Configuration
docs.text:

Using npx (Recommended)Using Global Install 
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "hawkeye": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "hawkeye-mcp-server"],
      "env": {
        "HAWKEYE_EMAIL": "your-email@company.com",
        "HAWKEYE_PASSWORD": "your-password",
        "HAWKEYE_BASE_URL": "https://app.neubird.ai/api"
      }
    }
  }
}

Pros:

  • ✅ No installation required
  • ✅ Always uses latest version
  • ✅ Fastest to set up

First install globally:

npm install -g hawkeye-mcp-server

Then configure:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "hawkeye": {
      "command": "hawkeye-mcp",
      "env": {
        "HAWKEYE_EMAIL": "your-email@company.com",
        "HAWKEYE_PASSWORD": "your-password",
        "HAWKEYE_BASE_URL": "https://app.neubird.ai/api"
      }
    }
  }
}

Pros:

  • ✅ Faster startup time
  • ✅ Works offline (once installed)
  • ✅ Version control

Replace credentials

Don't forget to replace the example email, password, and URL with your actual Hawkeye credentials!

docs.title: Method 2: Project Configuration (For Teams)
docs.text: Use this method to share Hawkeye MCP configuration with your team via version control.

docs.title: 1. Create Project Configuration File
docs.text:
In your project root directory, create .mcp.json:

# Navigate to your project
cd /path/to/your/project

# Create the config file
touch .mcp.json

# Open in editor
code .mcp.json

docs.title: 2. Add Hawkeye Configuration
docs.text:
Add the same configuration as above to .mcp.json.

Project vs User scope

  • Project config (.mcp.json) can be committed to git and shared with team
  • User config (~/.claude.json) is personal and not shared
  • You can use both - project config takes precedence

docs.title: Method 3: CLI Installation
docs.text:
Use Claude Code's CLI to add servers programmatically:

# Add to user scope (all projects)
claude mcp add --scope user --transport stdio hawkeye -- npx -y hawkeye-mcp-server

# Add to project scope (current project only)
claude mcp add --scope project --transport stdio hawkeye -- npx -y hawkeye-mcp-server

Note: You'll still need to manually edit the config file to add environment variables (credentials).

docs.title: Restart Claude Code
docs.text:
Restart Claude Code to load the new configuration:

# Exit Claude Code if running (Ctrl+D)
# Then restart
claude

/mcp

You should see: - ✔ hawkeye server listed as "connected" - Your config file location shown (either ~/.claude.json or .mcp.json)

List available MCP tools

docs.title: When to Use Manual Investigations
docs.text:
• Proactive analysis - Investigate potential issues before they become alerts
  • Historical research - Analyze past incidents not captured as alerts
  • What-if scenarios - Test hypothetical situations
  • Training - Create example investigations for documentation
  • Testing - Validate system behavior without waiting for real alerts

docs.title: Creating a Manual Investigation
docs.text:
Good prompt (specific):

Investigate high latency in payment-service between 2pm-3pm EST on Jan 15, 2025.
Users reported checkout taking 30+ seconds instead of the usual 2 seconds.

Bad prompt (too vague):

Something went wrong with the payment service

Claude will use hawkeye_create_manual_investigation:

✓ Created manual investigation
Session UUID: abc-123-def-456
Status: Running

Investigation will complete in 2-5 minutes.
Use hawkeye_get_rca to retrieve results.

docs.title: Prompt Quality Guidelines
docs.text:
✅ Include these details:

  1. Service/Resource names - Which components are involved?
  2. Time frame - When did this occur or should be analyzed?
  3. Symptoms - What behavior are you seeing?
  4. Context - Any additional relevant information?

❌ Avoid:

  • Vague descriptions ("something broke")
  • No timeframe ("recently", "earlier")
  • Missing service names ("the API", "the database")

Example prompts:

Investigate memory leak in user-api pods in production namespace.
Started around 8am UTC today, memory usage climbing from 500MB to 2GB.

Analyze database connection pool exhaustion in postgres-primary.
Between 1pm-2pm EST yesterday. Connection count hit max of 100.

Check for cascading failures in microservices during deployment.
January 10, 2025 at 3:15pm UTC. Multiple services returned 503 errors.

docs.title: Agent Behavior
docs.text:
If your prompt is too vague, Claude will ask clarifying questions:

You: Investigate the payment issue

Claude: I need more details to create an effective investigation:
- Which payment service? (payment-api, payment-processor, etc.)
- When did this occur? (specific date/time or time range)
- What symptoms did you observe? (errors, slow response, failures?)
- Any other context? (deployment, traffic spike, etc.)

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
Complete manual investigation workflow:

1. Create investigation
   Investigate API latency spike in checkout-service on Jan 15 between 2-3pm EST

2. Wait for completion (2-5 minutes)
   Check status with: What's the status of this investigation?

3. Get RCA
   Show me the root cause analysis

4. Ask follow-ups
   What caused the latency spike?
   Were there any related infrastructure changes?

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
The tool accepts:

Parameter Type Default Description prompt string required Investigation description (min 10 chars) project_uuid string optional Uses default project if not specified wait_for_completion boolean false Return immediately or wait for results max_wait_seconds number 360 Max wait time (investigations take 2-5 min)

Using Default Project

If you've set a default project with hawkeye_set_default_project, you don't need to specify project_uuid. Manual investigations will automatically use your default project.

docs.title: Pattern 1: API Latency
docs.text:
Symptoms: Slow API responses, timeouts

Investigation approach: 1. Check APM traces (Datadog, New Relic) 2. Review database query performance 3. Check external API dependencies 4. Examine cache hit rates 5. Review resource utilization

Common causes: - Missing database indexes - Inefficient queries - External API slowdowns - Cache misses - Insufficient resources

docs.title: Pattern 2: Memory Leaks
docs.text:
Symptoms: Increasing memory, eventual OOM crash

Investigation approach: 1. Review memory growth timeline 2. Check for unclosed connections 3. Look for accumulating caches 4. Examine heap dumps 5. Review recent code changes

Common causes: - Unclosed database connections - Event listener leaks - Growing in-memory caches - Circular references

docs.title: Pattern 3: Database Issues
docs.text:
Symptoms: Slow queries, connection timeouts

Investigation approach: 1. Check slow query logs 2. Review connection pool metrics 3. Examine table locks 4. Check index usage 5. Review database resource metrics

Common causes: - Missing indexes - Lock contention - Connection pool exhaustion - Long-running transactions - Inefficient queries

docs.title: Pattern 4: Deployment Failures
docs.text:
Symptoms: Service crashes after deployment

Investigation approach: 1. Compare deployment manifests 2. Review container startup logs 3. Check environment variables 4. Examine health check failures 5. Review resource limits

Common causes: - Configuration errors - Missing environment variables - Insufficient resources - Database migration failures - Incompatible dependencies

docs.title: Phases at a Glance
docs.text:
📦 Prerequisites & Installation (5-10 minutes)

  • Install Hawkeye MCP Server and configure your AI client
  • See Installation Guide for details

🔗 Phase 1: Add Connections (10-15 minutes)

  • Connect your cloud providers (AWS, Azure, GCP)
  • Link monitoring tools (Datadog, PagerDuty, etc.)
  • Wait for initial data sync

📁 Phase 2: Create Project (5 minutes)

  • Set up your first project
  • Link connections to the project
  • Set as default project

🔍 Phase 3: Run First Investigation (5-10 minutes)

  • Create a manual investigation to test the system
  • Review the RCA (Root Cause Analysis)
  • Understand the investigation output

🎯 Phase 4: Find & Investigate Real Alerts (10-15 minutes)

  • List uninvestigated alerts from your systems
  • Investigate a real incident
  • Execute corrective actions

📋 Phase 5: Configure Instructions (15-20 minutes)

  • Add SYSTEM instructions for context
  • Create FILTER instructions to reduce noise
  • Test RCA instructions on past incidents

Total time: 50-75 minutes

Phased Approach

You don't need to complete everything in one sitting! Many teams split this across multiple sessions: - Day 1: Install + Connections + Project (20-30 min) - Day 2: First investigations + Instructions (30-45 min)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, ensure you have:

  • Hawkeye account (book demo if needed)

docs.title: Phase 1: Add Connections

docs.text: Test the system with a manual investigation before waiting for real alerts.

docs.title: Step 3.1: Create a Test Investigation
docs.text:

Investigate potential memory leak in user-api pods that I noticed this morning.

No alerts fired yet but trending upward.

Claude will use hawkeye_create_manual_investigation:

✓ Created manual investigation
Session UUID: xyz-789-abc-123
Status: Running

Investigation will complete in 2-5 minutes.
Analyzing:
- CloudWatch metrics for memory usage
- Pod restart patterns
- Application logs
- Resource allocation changes

docs.title: Step 3.2: Wait for Completion
docs.text:

docs.title: Step 3.3: Review the RCA
docs.text:
Show me the root cause analysis

Claude uses hawkeye_get_rca:

Root Cause Analysis
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Incident: Memory Leak - user-api
Severity: P2 (High)
Duration: Ongoing (2 hours)
Status: Active

ROOT CAUSE:
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Memory leak caused by unclosed database connections
in the user session handler. Connection pool reached
maximum capacity, preventing cleanup of old connections.

TIMELINE:
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
08:00 UTC - Normal memory usage (500MB)
08:15 UTC - Gradual increase begins
09:00 UTC - Memory at 800MB (60% increase)
09:30 UTC - Connection pool at 85% capacity
10:00 UTC - Memory at 1.2GB (140% increase)
10:15 UTC - Connection pool at max (100 connections)

CORRECTIVE ACTIONS:
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Immediate:
1. Restart affected pods to clear connections

   kubectl rollout restart deployment/user-api

2. Temporarily increase connection pool timeout

   kubectl set env deployment/user-api DB_POOL_TIMEOUT=30000

Long-term fixes:
1. Fix connection leak in code (user-session.js:45)
2. Implement connection pool monitoring
3. Add automated cleanup for stale connections

TIME SAVED:
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Manual investigation time: ~30 minutes
Hawkeye investigation time: 2 minutes
Time saved: 28 minutes ⚡

docs.text:
Every RCA includes:

  1. Incident Summary - What happened and severity
  2. Root Cause - Why it happened with technical details
  3. Timeline - Chronological event sequence
  4. Corrective Actions - Ready-to-execute fixes
  5. Time Savings - Efficiency metrics

Test Complete!

If you got a detailed RCA like above, your setup is working correctly! The system successfully: - Connected to your cloud provider - Analyzed metrics and logs - Generated actionable insights

docs.title: Phase 5: Configure Instructions
docs.text: Fine-tune how Hawkeye investigates incidents by adding instructions.

docs.title: Step 5.1: Understand Instruction Types
docs.text: Type Purpose When to Use Example SYSTEM Provide context about your architecture Always (start with 1-2) "We use microservices on Kubernetes" FILTER Reduce noise by filtering low-priority alerts When getting too many alerts "Only investigate P1 and P2 incidents" RCA Guide investigation steps for specific scenarios For common incident types "For database issues, check slow queries first" GROUPING Group related alerts together When seeing duplicate alerts "Group alerts from same service within 5 min"

docs.title: Step 5.2: Add SYSTEM Instruction
docs.text:
Provide high-level context:

Create a SYSTEM instruction for my Production project:

"Our infrastructure runs on AWS EKS with 15 microservices.
We use PostgreSQL for databases and Redis for caching.
Peak traffic is 9am-5pm EST. We have auto-scaling enabled
for all services with min 2, max 10 replicas."

Claude uses hawkeye_create_project_instruction:

✓ Created SYSTEM instruction
Type: SYSTEM
Status: Active

This context will be used in all future investigations
to provide more relevant analysis.

docs.title: Step 5.3: Add FILTER Instruction
docs.text:
Reduce noise:

Create a FILTER instruction for my Production project:

"Only investigate incidents with severity P1 (Critical)
or P2 (High). Ignore P3 and P4 alerts unless they occur
more than 5 times in 10 minutes."

This prevents low-priority alerts from creating unnecessary investigations.

docs.title: Step 5.4: Add RCA Instruction
docs.text:
Guide investigation for common scenarios:

Create an RCA instruction for my Production project:

"For database-related incidents:
1. Check for slow queries (>1 second)
2. Review connection pool usage
3. Analyze index usage with EXPLAIN
4. Check for table locks or deadlocks
5. Suggest specific index improvements"

docs.title: Step 5.5: Test Instructions on Past Incidents
docs.text:
Before deploying instructions broadly, test them:

I want to test this new RCA instruction on the database
incident from yesterday. Apply it to that session and rerun
the investigation.

Claude will: 1. Apply instruction to specific session 2. Rerun the investigation 3. Compare new RCA vs original 4. Help you decide if it improved the results

See Testing Instructions Guide for detailed workflow.

docs.title: Testing Instructions
docs.text: Learn to test and refine investigation instructions before deploying them.

docs.title: Why Test Instructions?
docs.text:
Problem: Bad instructions affect ALL future investigations.

Solution: Test instructions on past investigations before adding to your project.

graph LR
    A[Write Instruction] --> B[Validate]
    B --> C[Apply to Test Session]
    C --> D[Rerun Investigation]
    D --> E[Compare RCAs]
    E -->|Better| F[Add to Project]
    E -->|Worse| G[Refine & Retry]

docs.title: 5-Step Testing Workflow
docs.text:
1. Pick a past investigation as test case
2. Validate your instruction
3. Apply instruction to that session
4. Rerun the investigation
5. Compare new RCA with original

Only add to project if the new RCA is better!

docs.title: Step 1: Choose a Test Session
docs.text:
Find a past investigation to test against:

Show me investigations from the last 7 days

Pick one that represents the type of incident your instruction targets.

Example: 

I want to test an instruction for database issues.
Show me database-related investigations.

Save the session_uuid from the results.

docs.title: Step 2: Write Your Instruction
docs.text:
Draft the instruction content:

Example - Database Investigation: 

For database performance issues:
1. Check EXPLAIN ANALYZE output for slow queries
2. Identify missing indexes
3. Review connection pool utilization
4. Check for lock contention
5. Suggest specific index improvements with CREATE INDEX commands

docs.title: Step 3: Validate the Instruction
docs.text:
Validate this RCA instruction:

"For database performance issues:
1. Check EXPLAIN ANALYZE output for slow queries
2. Identify missing indexes
3. Review connection pool utilization
4. Check for lock contention
5. Suggest specific index improvements with CREATE INDEX commands"

Uses hawkeye_validate_instruction:

✓ Instruction validated successfully

Generated name: "Database Performance Investigation Steps"
Type: RCA
Refined content: [AI-improved version]

The instruction is ready to test.

docs.title: Step 4: Apply to Test Session
docs.text:
Apply this instruction to session abc-123-def-456

Uses hawkeye_apply_session_instruction:

✓ Instruction applied to test session

The instruction has been added as a session-specific
override. It will ONLY affect this session when rerun.

Next step: Rerun the investigation to see the impact.

docs.title: Step 5: Rerun the Investigation
docs.text:
Rerun session abc-123-def-456 with the new instruction

Uses hawkeye_rerun_session:

🔍 Rerunning investigation...
⏳ Applying new instruction... (5s)
⏳ Re-analyzing data... (30s)
⏳ Generating new RCA... (15s)

✓ Investigation complete! (50s total)

docs.title: Step 6: Compare Results
docs.text:
Show me the RCA for session abc-123-def-456

Uses hawkeye_get_rca:

Root Cause Analysis (UPDATED)
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

[NEW] EXPLAIN ANALYZE output included:
┌────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ Seq Scan on users (cost=0..125000)    │
│   Filter: (last_login < now() - 30d)  │
│   Rows: 50000 | Time: 850ms           │
└────────────────────────────────────────┘

[NEW] Missing Index Identified:
CREATE INDEX CONCURRENTLY idx_users_last_login
  ON users(last_login);

Estimated improvement: 850ms → 5ms (99.4% faster)

[NEW] Connection Pool Analysis:
- Current utilization: 95/100 connections
- Peak during incident: 100/100 (exhausted)
- Recommendation: Increase pool size to 150

The new RCA includes specific actionable insights
that were missing in the original investigation!

docs.title: Step 7: Decision Time
docs.text:
Compare with original RCA:

Aspect Original RCA New RCA Root cause identified ✓ Yes ✓ Yes Specific query shown ✗ No ✓ Yes EXPLAIN output ✗ No ✓ Yes Index suggestion ✗ Generic ✓ Specific Performance estimate ✗ No ✓ Yes Connection pool analysis ✗ No ✓ Yes

Verdict: New RCA is significantly better!

docs.title: Step 8: Add to Project
docs.text:
This instruction improved the RCA. Add it to my Production project.

Uses hawkeye_create_project_instruction:

✓ Created RCA instruction for Production project
Name: "Database Performance Investigation Steps"
Status: Active

All future database investigations will use this
instruction to provide detailed performance analysis.

docs.title: FILTER Instructions
docs.text:
Purpose: Reduce noise by filtering out low-value alerts

Example: 

Only investigate incidents with:
- Severity P1 or P2
- Affecting production environment
- Not from load testing systems

Testing: 1. Apply to multiple past sessions 2. Check if important alerts would be filtered 3. Ensure noise is actually reduced

docs.title: SYSTEM Instructions
docs.text:
Purpose: Provide architectural context

Example: 

Our infrastructure:
- Microservices on AWS EKS (5 services)
- PostgreSQL RDS with read replicas
- Redis ElastiCache for caching
- Datadog APM for distributed tracing
- Peak traffic: 1000 req/sec 2-6pm EST

Testing: 1. Apply to various incident types 2. Check if context improves root cause analysis 3. Ensure no irrelevant information

docs.title: GROUPING Instructions
docs.text:
Purpose: Group related alerts together

Example: 

Group incidents when:
- Same service and error type within 15 minutes
- Same root cause (deployment, database, etc.)
- Cascading failures from single source

Testing: 1. Review past incidents that should be grouped 2. Apply instruction and rerun 3. Verify correct grouping behavior

docs.title: RCA Instructions
docs.text:
Purpose: Guide investigation behavior

Example: 

For API latency issues:
1. Check Datadog APM traces first
2. Identify slowest span in trace
3. Review database query performance
4. Check external API timeouts
5. Examine cache hit rates
6. Provide specific optimization recommendations

Testing: 1. Apply to past latency incidents 2. Check if investigation follows steps 3. Verify better remediation suggestions

docs.title: A/B Testing Instructions
docs.text:
Test two different approaches:

Approach A: 

For deployment failures, check container logs first

Approach B: 

For deployment failures, check health check endpoints first

  1. Apply Approach A to session-1, rerun, save RCA
  2. Apply Approach B to session-1, rerun, save RCA
  3. Compare which provides better insights
  4. Use the better one

docs.title: Multi-Session Testing
docs.text:
Test instruction across multiple sessions:

# Test against 5 different database incidents
Apply this instruction to sessions: [uuid1, uuid2, uuid3, uuid4, uuid5]
Rerun all of them
Compare all RCAs

If ⅘ improved, the instruction is likely good.

docs.title: Negative Testing
docs.text:
Test that instructions don't harm unrelated investigations:

# Instruction for database issues
# Test on API latency incident (unrelated)

Ensure the instruction doesn't degrade investigations for other incident types.

docs.title: Do's ✅
docs.text:
• Be specific - "Check PostgreSQL slow queries" vs "Check database"
  • Provide steps - Numbered investigation workflow
  • Include context - Architecture details, business logic
  • Test thoroughly - Multiple sessions, different incident types
  • Iterate - Refine based on results

docs.title: Don'ts ❌
docs.text:
• Don't be vague - "Investigate thoroughly" doesn't help
  • Don't contradict - Ensure instructions don't conflict
  • Don't over-constrain - Allow flexibility in investigation
  • Don't skip testing - Always test before deploying
  • Don't set and forget - Review and update regularly

docs.title: Scenario 1: Database Query Optimization
docs.text:
Instruction: 

For slow database queries:
1. Get EXPLAIN ANALYZE output
2. Identify missing indexes
3. Calculate selectivity of proposed indexes
4. Provide CREATE INDEX commands
5. Estimate performance improvement

Test on: - Slow query incidents (should improve) - Connection pool issues (should not degrade) - Database crashes (should not interfere)

docs.title: Scenario 2: Deployment Rollback
docs.text:
Instruction: 

For incidents following deployments:
1. Identify which service was deployed
2. Get deployment timestamp
3. Correlate incident timing with deployment
4. Provide rollback command if deployment is cause
5. List changed files in deployment

Test on: - Post-deployment failures (should improve) - Unrelated incidents during deployment window (should not blame deployment) - Successful deployments (should not create false positives)

docs.title: Scenario 3: Memory Leak Detection
docs.text:
Instruction: 

For memory-related incidents:
1. Plot memory growth timeline
2. Identify leak rate (MB/hour)
3. Check for unclosed connections
4. Review cache growth patterns
5. Examine heap dump if available
6. Suggest resource cleanup code

Test on: - Confirmed memory leaks (should improve) - Legitimate memory growth (traffic increase) (should distinguish) - CPU issues (should not confuse)

docs.title: Quantitative Metrics
docs.text:
RCA Quality Score: 

Show me the quality score before and after

  • Before: 75/100
  • After: 92/100
  • Improvement: +17 points ✓

Investigation Time: - Before: 60 seconds - After: 65 seconds - Overhead: +5 seconds (acceptable)

Completeness: - Before: 3 corrective actions - After: 5 corrective actions (2 more specific)

docs.title: Qualitative Assessment
docs.text:
Better RCA includes: - ✅ More specific root cause - ✅ Actionable remediation steps - ✅ Copy-paste ready commands - ✅ Preventive measures - ✅ Performance estimates

Watch out for: - ❌ Generic recommendations - ❌ Conflicting suggestions - ❌ Irrelevant information - ❌ Slower investigation time

docs.title: Refining Instructions
docs.text: If test results are mixed:

docs.title: Iteration 1: Too Generic
docs.text:
Original: 

Check for performance issues

Problem: Too vague, doesn't guide investigation

Refined: 

For performance issues:
1. Identify bottleneck (CPU, memory, I/O, network)
2. Get metrics for bottleneck resource
3. Find peak usage times
4. Correlate with application behavior

docs.title: Iteration 2: Too Specific
docs.text:
Original: 

Always check table users for lock contention

Problem: Too narrow, not applicable to all DB issues

Refined: 

For database lock issues:
1. Identify locked tables from pg_locks
2. Find blocking queries
3. Check lock wait times
4. Suggest query optimization or table partitioning

docs.title: Iteration 3: Adding Context
docs.text:
Original: 

Check API response times

Enhanced: 

Check API response times:
- Normal: <100ms (p95)
- Degraded: 100-500ms
- Critical: >500ms
- Check /health endpoint separately (should be <10ms)

docs.title: hawkeye_investigate_alert
docs.text:
START a new investigation for an uninvestigated alert.

Parameters: - alert_id (string, required): Alert ID from incident_info.id - project_uuid (string, optional): Project UUID - wait_for_completion (boolean, optional): Wait for completion - max_wait_seconds (number, optional): Max wait time

Example:

docs.title: hawkeye_continue_investigation

Important: Use session_uuid from investigated sessions, not alert_id.

docs.title: Investigate an Alert
docs.text:
1. hawkeye_list_sessions (only_uninvestigated=true)
2. hawkeye_investigate_alert (with alert_id)
3. hawkeye_get_rca (get results)
4. hawkeye_continue_investigation (optional follow-up)

docs.title: Test an Instruction
docs.text:
1. hawkeye_validate_instruction
2. hawkeye_apply_session_instruction
3. hawkeye_rerun_session
4. hawkeye_get_rca (compare results)
5. hawkeye_create_project_instruction (if improved)

docs.title: Complete Onboarding
docs.text:
1. hawkeye_create_project
2. hawkeye_create_aws_connection
3. hawkeye_wait_for_connection_sync
4. hawkeye_add_connection_to_project
5. hawkeye_create_project_instruction (SYSTEM)
6. hawkeye_list_sessions (only_uninvestigated=true)
7. hawkeye_investigate_alert
